This patient presents with fatigue and weight loss. Laboratory testing reveals a positive HBsAg, high HBV viral load, and negative HBeAg. In combination, these findings suggest chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. This patient is started on antiviral therapy with entecavir, a nucleoside analog that inhibits DNA replication and transcription.

Hepatitis B medications can be divided into two groups based on their mechanism of action: nucleoside (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) or nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir) and interferons.

In infected cells, the nucleotide/nucleoside analogs are first phosphorylated by cellular enzymes into either a diphosphate or triphosphate form to resemble the natural nucleotides present in the cells. Viral DNA polymerase will try to use these analogues for DNA synthesis. However, once these analogs are incorporated into the growing DNA strand, no additional nucleotides can be added, and DNA synthesis stops.

Side effects of nucleotide/nucleoside analogs include nephrotoxicity (adefovir), headache, dizziness, fatigue, and nausea. HBV strains can develop resistance to medications from this class through mutations in the DNA polymerase enzyme.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cell entry:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents viruses from entering the cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used to manage HIV infection, not hepatitis B infection.  
✅ Replication of viral DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Post-translational modifications:
Incorrect: Protease inhibitors are synthetic drugs that inhibit the action of HIV-1 protease, an enzyme that cleaves precursor proteins into smaller fragments. These fragments are needed for viral growth, infectivity, and replication. Examples of protease inhibitors include ritonavir and indinavir.  
❌ Translation of viral proteins:
Incorrect: Interferon activates host cell ribonucleases, which preferentially degrade viral mRNA and prevent translation of viral mRNA into proteins. In contrast, entecavir is a nucleotide analog that inhibits the transcription of viral DNA into mRNA  
❌ Release from host cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that blocks the enzyme neuraminidase. NAIs can be used to treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.

The patient has experienced a 6-month history of progressive tiredness associated with dull achy pain in the knees, hips, and shoulders. He has no significant past medical history, and he does not regularly take medications. He has a history of intravenous drug use and was undomiciled in his early 30s. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. This patient has fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, positive hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibody titers, and high levels of HCV RNA. These findings are consistent with HCV infection. He was most likely started on ribavirin for management of this infection.

Ribavirin is a nucleoside analog that is initially phosphorylated to a monophosphate form. Ribavirin monophosphate resembles inosine-5′-phosphate (IMP) and binds to IMP dehydrogenase, which converts IMP into xanthosine monophosphate. Xanthosein monophosphate then goes on to make guanine nucleotides. The binding of ribavirin to IMP dehydrogenase inhibits the enzyme, thereby reducing guanine nucleotide production and viral RNA synthesis.

Side effects of systemic ribavirin therapy include dose-dependent hemolytic anemia and hyperuricemia. Aerosolized ribavirin may cause conjunctival and bronchial irritation. Ribavirin is a known human teratogen and is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Similarly, sofosbuvir is a nucleotide analog used to treat HCV infection. This medication inhibits HCV RNA polymerase. When used alone or in combination with interferon or ribavirin, sofosbuvir can achieve very high cure rates (90–95%).  

Option Analysis

❌ Oseltamivir:
Incorrect: Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor. It blocks the function of neuraminidase, an enzyme produced by the influenza virus, and prevents the release of newly synthesized virus from the host cell. Furthermore, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C infection, which is not treated with oseltamivir.  
❌ Entecavir:
Incorrect: Entecavir is a nucleoside analog incorporated into growing viral DNA strands to block further genetic material synthesis. It is indicated in chronic hepatitis B virus infection management, not hepatitis C virus infection.  
✅ Ribavirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Enfuvirtide:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.  
❌ Interferon-gamma:
Incorrect: Interferon-gamma is a cytokine that activates macrophages and induces class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) expression. Exogenous interferon-gamma can be used therapeutically in chronic granulomatous disease and osteopetrosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with gradual onset of abdominal pain, nausea, and fatigue over the last three weeks. She has had low-grade fevers for the past five days. She does not regularly drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. She has been with a new sexual partner for the last six months who is biologically male and has a history of hepatitis B infection. They use condoms occasionally. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg. Physical exam reveals scleral icterus and tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant on abdominal exam. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows mild liver enlargement and a normal gallbladder. Which of the following laboratory results would be most consistent with this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, low-grade fever, scleral icterus, and liver enlargement are highly suggestive of acute hepatitis B infection given her recent exposure to the virus through sexual contact. Diagnosis of hepatitis B relies on serologic testing for viral antigens and antibodies to determine whether infection is present and to indicate the stage of the disease. In acute infection Hep B surface antigen is often the first marker to become positive as seen in this patient, indicating that the hepatitis B virus is present. The surface antibodies (HBsAb) are negative in acute infection since the body has not yet formed a neutralizing antibody to the virus. Core IgM antibodies rise before core IgG in acute infection as seen in this patient; and during the window period, Anti-HBc IgM may be the sole available marker of infection. Anti-HBc IgG will rise later and persist longer.

In chronic hepatitis B infection, neutralizing antibodies never form and HBsAb will remain negative. HBsAg will stay positive for more than six months as the virus continues to circulate. Anti-HBc IgM will gradually wane, and IgG will be the persisting core antibody in chronic infection.

When the body is successful at eradicating the virus after an acute infection, surface antibodies will be detectable and usually stay present for life. HBsAg will be negative as the virus has been cleared. Anti-HBc IgG will remain positive as an indicator of prior infection.

Another important scenario to consider is when the serologic testing shows a positive HBsAb, but all other serologic markers are negative. In this scenario, the patient is immune to hepatitis B through vaccination. Vaccines for hepatitis B only contain surface antigens. Antibodies to the core will only occur after a true infection.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect:  This would be consistent with immunity by vaccination to hepatitis B where only the surface antibody is positive.
❌ :
Incorrect: This would be consistent with immunity to hepatitis B from prior cleared infection where core IgG antibodies and surface antibodies are present.   
✅ :
Correct:  See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This would be consistent with chronic hepatitis B infection where surface antibodies have not developed and core IgM antibodies have waned but core IgG antibodies persist.   
❌ :
Incorrect:  The nature of the presenting symptoms and known hepatitis B exposure through sexual contact make acute hepatitis B infection likely in this patient.  Negative serology would suggest a different etiology.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of several weeks of intense itching, which is localized around the anus. The patient has not had any recent travel, sexual contacts, fever, dysuria, or diarrhea. The patient works as a daycare teacher. The patient’s current pregnancy is uncomplicated. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals severe excoriations and erythema in the perianal region. The scotch tape test is positive. Which of the following is the preferred medication for the management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with perianal itching and a positive scotch tape test. These findings are consistent with enterobiasis caused by the pathogen Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm). Pyrantel pamoate is the preferred alternative to albendazole in pregnant women due to the latter’s teratogenicity.  

Pyrantel pamoate is taken perorally and is poorly absorbed. As a result, it only affects nematodes in the gastrointestinal tract. The medication works by stimulating parasitic nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, which causes uncontrolled muscle contractions, paralysis, and subsequent expulsion of the parasites through the stool.    

Pyrantel pamoate can be used as an alternative to bendazoles for many of the same nematode infections. However, the medication does not affect whipworms or tapeworms.  

Side effects are mild and include headaches and gastrointestinal symptoms.  



Option Analysis

❌ Praziquantel:
Incorrect: Praziquantel increases the permeability of parasitic cellular membranes to calcium ions; thereby, leading to muscle paralysis and death. It is the first-line therapy against most trematodes (flukes) and cestodes (tapeworms). It is not effective against Enterobius vermicularis.  
❌ Amphotericin B:
Incorrect: This patient presents with perianal itching and a positive scotch tape test revealing the presence of eggs in the perianal region. These findings are suggestive of infection by the roundworm Enterobius vermicularis. Amphotericin B is not used in the treatment of infections caused by this pathogen.  
✅ Pyrantel pamoate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Albendazole:
Incorrect: Although albendazole is the first-line medication for the management of enterobiasis, it should be avoided in pregnant women due to the potential for teratogenicity.  
❌ Diethylcarbamazine:
Incorrect: Diethylcarbamazine is used to treat infections by Loa loa and Wuchereria bancrofti. It is not effective against pinworms.

choices.text: Swimming in a warm-water lake in the United States

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of abdominal pain, malaise, dark urine and elevation of transaminases and bilirubin is consistent with acute hepatitis. The results of the viral hepatitis panel indicate infection with Hepatitis A virus (HAV). Consuming contaminated food such as raw shellfish (e.g. oysters) is a risk factor for acquiring HAV.

Patients infected with HAV can be asymptomatic, or they may present with symptoms of acute hepatitis, or even fulminant hepatic failure. Common symptoms of acute hepatitis include abdominal pain, malaise, fever, dark urine, pale colored stools, nausea, vomiting, lack of appetite, and jaundice. Physical examination may reveal tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, hepatomegaly, scleral icterus, jaundice of the skin, and fever.  Infection with Hepatitis E virus (HEV) typically presents similarly.

The primary route of spread of HAV is via the fecal-oral route. The most common cause is ingestion of contaminated food, such as raw shellfish, or contaminated water, from areas with poor sanitation and areas where the virus is endemic. Additional risk factors include household contact with a person who has the infection, sexual contact with a person who has the infection, and living with large numbers of people, such as in a residential institution. Outbreaks have also been associated with daycare centers. Hepatitis E virus is primarily spread through the fecal-oral route as well, with similar risk factors to HAV, but HEV can also more often be spread through contaminated blood products, including from blood transfusions in areas where the virus is endemic.

Option Analysis

✅ Consuming raw oysters:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Swimming in a warm-water lake in the United States:
Incorrect: Although Hepatitis A (HAV) can be spread through contaminated water, infection occurs by ingesting the water and not usually from swimming in it. Infection with HAV from swimming is extremely rare and is more likely to occur when the contamination occurs in a contained body of water such as a swimming pool or a jacuzzi tub. Direct consumption of the virus from eating raw shellfish is a much more likely source of infection.  
❌ Getting a blood transfusion:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A virus is found in blood, but it is primarily spread through the fecal-oral route from ingesting water or food that has been contaminated with the virus. Blood-borne exposure would be a much less likely source of infection from Hepatitis A.  
❌ Getting new tattoos:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A virus is found in blood, but is primarily spread through the fecal-oral route from ingesting water or food that has been contaminated by the virus. Blood-borne exposure would be a much less likely source of infection from Hepatitis A than consuming raw shellfish.  
❌ Traveling to Iceland:
Incorrect: Travel to areas where Hepatitis A is endemic in the population and resources for sanitation are limited is a risk factor for transmission of HAV, as humans are the only known reservoir for the virus. However, Iceland has a low incidence of Hepatitis A and is not considered a resource-limited area, making the likelihood of infection while traveling there low.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of decreased appetite, frequent belching, and unintentional weight loss of 8 pounds over the past two months. He also reports intermittent epigastric pain which worsens after meals. His diet consists of red meat and spicy foods. He does not use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). The patient smokes half a pack per day of cigarettes and drinks 1-2 beers daily. His medical history is unremarkable, and there is no history of recent gastrointestinal infections or travel. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the epigastric region. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Upper endoscopy (EGD) shows hyperemia, enlargement of mucosal folds, and nodularity in the gastric antrum and body. Biopsy results show chronic active gastritis with glandular atrophy and the presence of spiral-shaped bacteria within the gastric epithelium. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Smoking cessation and counseling on alcohol use
Proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin

questions.solution:
his patient presents with decreased appetite, frequent belching, unintentional weight loss, and epigastric pain and tenderness. EGD shows hyperemia, enlarged mucosal folds, and nodularity, and biopsy results indicate chronic active gastritis with glandular atrophy and the presence of spiral-shaped bacteria. The most likely diagnosis is H. pylori gastritis. The best next step in management is triple therapy, which consists of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) to reduce gastric acid secretion, plus clarithromycin, and amoxicillin (or metronidazole in case of penicillin allergy) to eradicate the H. pylori infection. This regimen is typically administered for 14 days.        

The treatment of gastritis varies depending on the underlying cause. Stress gastritis is managed with PPIs or H2 blockers for acid suppression and addressing underlying stressors (e.g., burns, severe illness). Chemical gastritis, caused by NSAIDs, alcohol, or bile reflux, requires discontinuation of the offending agent along with PPIs or H2 blockers. Autoimmune gastritis involves vitamin B12 supplementation, PPIs for symptom management, and lifestyle modifications. Reactive gastritis should be treated by removing the irritant along with PPIs or H2 blockers plus sucralfate to protect the gastric mucosa.    

Option Analysis

❌ Proton pump inhibitor:
Incorrect: While PPIs are part of the treatment regimen for H. pylori gastritis, monotherapy with a PPI alone is insufficient to eradicate the infection and address the underlying cause of the gastritis.  
❌ Smoking cessation and counseling on alcohol use:
Incorrect: While smoking cessation and reducing alcohol intake are beneficial for overall health and may improve gastritis symptoms, they would not directly treat the H. pylori infection which is responsible for the patient's condition.  
❌  Dietary modifications and probiotics:
Incorrect: Dietary modifications and probiotics can support gastrointestinal health but are not sufficient as primary treatments for H. pylori gastritis. Eradicating the infection requires a specific regimen of PPIs and antibiotics. 
✅ Proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sucralfate:
Incorrect: Sucralfate can be used to protect the gastric mucosa and aid in healing ulcers, but it would not address the underlying H. pylori infection.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain for eight days. He has had more than five episodes of diarrhea per day and bright red blood was noted to be mixed in the stool today. He had mild nausea at the onset of the illness but has not vomited. The patient reports that he ate grilled chicken last week at a restaurant that recently was in the news for having a Campylobacter outbreak. He does not have any chronic medical conditions. He has not taken antibiotics recently and has not travelled. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg. On examination, the patient is awake and alert. Mucus membranes are mildly dry. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits other than mild tachycardia. There is mild diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen but no guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies are shown below. A stool sample is collected. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

questions.solution:
This child presenting with bloody diarrhea and fever after consuming poultry during a Campylobacter outbreak likely has bacterial gastroenteritis. Given his stable vital signs, mild dehydration without electrolyte abnormalities, and lack of vomiting, a trial of oral rehydration is the best initial approach to rehydration. Antibiotics are rarely indicated in cases of acute gastroenteritis; but given this child’s fever, bloody stools, and length of the illness, it is reasonable to start empiric antibiotic treatment with azithromycin.  

The acute management of a pediatric patient with diarrhea depends first on the child's stability. Diarrhea can cause severe hypovolemia, critical electrolyte disturbances, and significant blood loss, all of which require emergent correction. The management of a child in stable condition with mild or moderate dehydration begins with rehydration therapy, preferably by the oral route. Evidence suggests that patients with gastroenteritis can maintain a regular diet, as food restrictions, such as avoidance of dairy or solid foods, have not been shown to be of benefit. Loperamide should be avoided in children with diarrhea when bloody stools or fever are present as it can prolong the length and worsen the severity of infection. Most cases of bacterial gastroenteritis are self-limited; antibiotics are typically reserved for patients with severe disease or those who are at risk for severe disease (e.g. immunocompromised). Signs of severe disease include bloody stools, high fever, evidence of extraintestinal infection, worsening symptoms, and symptoms lasting longer than one week. 

Option Analysis

✅ Oral rehydration and oral azithromycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral rehydration and loperamide:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration is the preferred method of rehydration therapy in stable patients with mild dehydration, normal electrolytes, and no emesis. However, loperamide should be avoided given the bloody stools and fever seen in this patient. There is concern that loperamide can prolong the length and worsen the severity of infection. 
❌ Intravenous rehydration and fecal calprotectin testing:
Incorrect: A trial of oral rehydration is preferred in most stable children with gastroenteritis. Fecal calprotectin is used to evaluate patients with chronic diarrhea that contains blood to evaluate for inflammatory bowel disease. This patient’s short duration of symptoms and presumed source of infection is more suggestive of an infectious cause of diarrhea, and a fecal calprotectin is not necessary. 
❌  Intravenous rehydration and intravenous ciprofloxacin:
Incorrect: Given this child’s mild dehydration and hemodynamic stability, a trial of oral rehydration is preferable. This patient does not require intravenous antibiotics. Oral azithromycin is appropriate and would be preferred over ciprofloxacin given this patient’s age.  
❌ Intravenous rehydration and supportive care:
Incorrect: Given this child’s mild dehydration and hemodynamic stability, a trial of oral rehydration is preferable to intravenous fluids. Additionally, this patient would benefit from antibiotics, given the bloody stools, fever, and length of illness. Since he is also at risk for infection with Campylobacter, azithromycin is the most appropriate choice.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of sudden-onset vomiting, abdominal cramps, and watery diarrhea. A parent reports that symptoms began shortly after a birthday party where the child ate potato salad and cream-filled pastries. Temperature is 37.0 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 90 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the child appears fatigued with tacky mucous membranes and capillary refill of < 2 seconds. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value Result
 White blood cell (WBC) count 8,500/µL
 Hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL
 Platelet count 290,000/µL
 Sodium 138 mEq/L
 Potassium 4.1 mEq/L
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 12 mg/dL
 Fecal lactoferrin Negative
 Stool microscopy Gram-positive cocci in clusters
questions.solution:
This presentation is consistent with acute gastroenteritis resulting from Staphylococcus aureus infection, a toxin-mediated illness that typically presents with rapid onset vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramps within hours of consuming contaminated food. This patient’s history of eating high-risk foods such as potato salad, in addition to the stool microscopy showing gram-positive cocci in clusters, supports this diagnosis. S. aureus gastroenteritis is typically self-limited and resolves within 24-48 hours. The best management strategy is oral rehydration to correct fluid losses and antiemetics to reduce vomiting, ensuring adequate hydration and symptom control.

Management of acute pediatric gastroenteritis begins with assessing dehydration to guide fluid replacement. For mild to moderate dehydration, oral rehydration therapy with an oral rehydration solution is first-line if the child can drink. An antiemetic such as ondansetron can reduce vomiting and facilitate oral intake. Severe dehydration or shock requires intravenous isotonic fluids such as normal saline and hospital admission.

Antibiotics are not indicated for S. aureus preformed toxin-related illness and are generally avoided unless an invasive bacterial infection is suspected or confirmed. In children older than 6 months, zinc supplementation can reduce the duration and severity of diarrhea, with the strongest evidence in settings where zinc deficiency is common. Probiotics are not recommended routinely because evidence for benefit is mixed, although selected preparations may offer modest symptom reduction. Routine antimicrobial therapy and stool testing are not needed in uncomplicated presentations since most infections resolve with supportive care.   

Option Analysis

❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and laboratory findings are consistent with gastroenteritis caused by preformed enterotoxin from Staphylococcus aureus, for which azithromycin is not used to treat. It is reserved for specific invasive or febrile bacterial diarrheas such as Campylobacter jejuni or selected cases of traveler’s diarrhea based on severity and local resistance patterns.
✅ Oral rehydration and antiemetics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hospital admission for intravenous fluids:
Incorrect: This child presents without tachycardia, hypotension, or mental status changes, which indicates mild dehydration. Initial management should start with oral rehydration, using an antiemetic to facilitate intake. Intravenous fluids and admission are appropriate for severe dehydration, shock, or failure of oral therapy.
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and laboratory findings are consistent with gastroenteritis caused by preformed enterotoxin from Staphylococcus aureus, which this antibiotic does not treat. It is considered for pathogens such as Shigella or Yersinia, depending on local susceptibility.
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and laboratory findings are consistent with a S. aureus preformed toxin-related illness, for which doxycycline is not indicated. It may be used for Vibrio cholerae to reduce stool volume and duration.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to a primary care clinic by parents due to 15 days of watery diarrhea. The diarrhea is frequent, mucoid, and occasionally blood streaked. The child has had abdominal cramping, fatigue, and poor appetite. She has not had a fever or vomiting. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg. The child appears fatigued but alert. Dry mucous membranes and a capillary refill time of 2 seconds are noted. The abdomen is soft with mild diffuse tenderness but no guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is most likely to be present on further questioning? 

 Lab Test     Value    
 White blood cell (WBC) count     12,000/mm³    
 Hemoglobin     12.0 g/dL    
 Platelets     320,000/mm³    
 Serum sodium     134 mEq/L    
 Serum potassium     3.4 mEq/L    
 Serum bicarbonate     20 mEq/L    
 Stool culture     Positive for enteroaggregative E. coli

choices.text: Recent travel to a developing country
Family history of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

questions.solution:
This child presents with 15 days of subacute watery diarrhea which contains mucus and occasionally blood. Stool culture confirms an infection with enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC), a recognized cause of traveler's diarrhea, often associated with recent travel to developing countries where food and water contamination is common.        

The history and physical examination may provide valuable clues in identifying the causative organism in infectious gastroenteritis, which can then be confirmed with stool studies. To qualify as "subacute," diarrhea must persist for more than 14 days and may be accompanied by fever, malaise, anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal cramps.       
A focused history should assess the characteristics of the diarrhea (e.g., watery, bloody, mucous, greasy) as well as potential exposures, such as sick contacts, recent travel (e.g., EAEC is linked to travel to developing countries, while tropical areas are associated with Cyclospora, Cryptosporidium, and Entamoeba infections), antibiotic use, or ingestion of contaminated food and water. The physical exam should evaluate the severity of dehydration (e.g., tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, delayed capillary refill) and check for abdominal tenderness, which may suggest inflammation or infection.   

Option Analysis

❌ Recent consumption of reheated rice:
Incorrect: Reheated rice is typically associated with Bacillus cereus, which causes acute, self-limited gastroenteritis with symptoms of vomiting or diarrhea occurring within hours of ingestion. It is unrelated to enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) and would be unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s 2-week duration of symptoms.
✅ Recent travel to a developing country:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Family history of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS):
Incorrect: IBS is a chronic functional disorder and does not cause infectious diarrhea. It would not explain a stool culture positive for enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC). 
❌ Recent antibiotic use:
Incorrect: Antibiotic use is most strongly associated with Clostridioides difficile infection, not enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC). 
❌ Recent outdoor camping :
Incorrect: Outdoor camping is commonly linked to Giardia infection, which presents with foul-smelling, greasy stools, not the mucoid or bloody diarrhea seen with enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) in this case. The stool culture being positive for EAEC further suggests that Giardia is unlikely in this case.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by parents due to a 2-week history of diarrhea. The stools are watery, occur 5 to 6 times daily, and are occasionally accompanied by abdominal cramping. Parents report poor appetite and weight loss over the past two weeks. The child has no history of fever, vomiting, or blood in the stool. The family recently returned from a vacation where the child swam frequently in a public pool. Vital signs are within normal limits. The child appears tired but alert. Mucous membranes are dry, and capillary refill time is 2 seconds. Abdominal exam reveals mild, diffuse tenderness without guarding or rebound. Stool antigen testing is positive for Cryptosporidium. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The management of cryptosporidiosis, caused by Cryptosporidium, includes targeted antimicrobial therapy, oral rehydration, and maintaining a normal diet. Nitazoxanide is the first-line treatment for Cryptosporidium infection in immunocompetent children, as it shortens symptom duration and reduces stool frequency.       

Treatment of subacute infectious gastroenteritis begins with assessing hydration status and initiating supportive care, including oral rehydration solutions to correct dehydration. A normal diet should be continued to prevent malnutrition and promote recovery.        

Antimicrobial therapy is pathogen-specific and guided by results from stool culture, ova and parasite evaluation, and antigen testing. For bacterial causes, Clostridioides difficile is treated with oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin, while enteroaggregative Escherichia coli (EAEC) may be self-limited or treated with azithromycin to shorten the duration of illness. For parasitic infections, Giardia lamblia is treated with metronidazole, tinidazole, or nitazoxanide. Cryptosporidium is treated with nitazoxanide, while Cyclospora may be treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Entamoeba histolytica can be treated with metronidazole followed by paromomycin.  

Option Analysis

❌ Oral metronidazole:
Incorrect: Metronidazole is not effective against Cryptosporidium. It is used for other protozoal infections, such as Giardia lamblia or Entamoeba histolytica.
✅ Oral nitazoxanide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Loperamide:
Incorrect: Loperamide is an antidiarrheal, which is contraindicated in patients with infectious diarrhea as it may delay the clearance of the pathogen or toxins and increase the risk of complications. 
❌ Probiotic and lactose-free diet:
Incorrect: Probiotics may have a minor supportive role in some gastrointestinal conditions; however, they are not effective in treating Cryptosporidium infection. A lactose-free diet is not required unless the child develops transient lactose intolerance. 
❌ Oral vancomycin:
Incorrect: Vancomycin is effective for Clostridioides difficile infection, not Cryptosporidium. It has no role in treating parasitic infections.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of bloody diarrhea, nonbilious vomiting, and right lower quadrant abdominal cramps. Caregivers report the child has eaten very little during this time. The child attended a school picnic 5 days ago (i.e. 3 days before the onset of symptoms), and other children developed similar symptoms. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 108/70 mmHg, heart rate is 130 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On examination, mucous membranes are dry, and capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. Stool examination reveals fecal leukocytes. Which of the following organisms is most likely causing this patient’s diarrhea?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with vomiting, bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever that began 3 days after a school picnic. The presence of fecal leukocytes indicates inflammatory diarrhea. Of the listed options, Campylobacter jejuni is associated with gastroenteritis after ingestion of undercooked poultry and commonly causes inflammatory diarrhea, which will present with fecal leukocytes and blood on stool analysis.

The diagnostic evaluation for acute infectious gastroenteritis begins with a focused history and physical examination to assess dehydration and identify potential exposures. Because symptoms overlap across etiologies, stool testing is often needed for a definitive diagnosis. Fecal leukocyte stains, calprotectin, and lactoferrin can be used to differentiate noninflammatory (e.g., norovirus, adenovirus, S. aureus, B. cereus) from inflammatory causes. These causes can then be further subdivided by stool character into watery stool (e.g., Vibrio, nontyphoidal Salmonella, ETEC) or bloody or mucoid stool (e.g., Campylobacter, Shigella, Yersinia).

Stool culture and multiplex PCR can identify bacterial pathogens. Antigen or PCR testing for viral agents can be used when the results will change management. However, viral studies are often unnecessary in mild, self-limited diseases.

Option Analysis

❌ Norovirus:
Incorrect: Norovirus typically causes abrupt vomiting, abdominal cramps, and watery noninflammatory diarrhea in school or community outbreaks. Fecal leukocytes and visible blood are usually absent.
✅ Campylobacter jejuni:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacillus cereus:
Incorrect: Gastroenteritis due to B. cereus is toxin-mediated and noninflammatory. The emetic form follows reheated rice with rapid-onset vomiting. The diarrheal form follows meats, vegetables, or sauces and causes watery diarrhea without fecal leukocytes or blood.
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Preformed enterotoxin from S. aureus causes rapid-onset vomiting and diarrhea within hours after eating mayonnaise-containing picnic or buffet foods. The illness is noninflammatory, so fecal leukocytes and blood are typically absent.
❌ Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC):
Incorrect: ETEC produces heat-labile and heat-stable toxins that cause watery, non-bloody traveler’s diarrhea. Fecal leukocytes may be present, but the fever is mild or absent and vomiting is less common.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parent for the evaluation of perianal itching. A few weeks ago, the patient went on a camping trip, during which time he swam in the lake and stayed in a tent with several friends. After the trip, the patient developed anal pruritus that is most severe at night. The patient does not have diarrhea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows perianal excoriations. Cellulose adhesive tape is applied to the perianal area in the morning. Microscopic examination of the tape shows eggs that are asymmetrically flattened on one side, giving a characteristic "bean-shaped" appearance. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action for the drug most appropriate for the treatment of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Blocks acetylcholine at the myoneural junction.

questions.solution:
This patient presents with perianal itching (especially at night) and subsequent work-up reveals the presence of microscopic "bean-shaped" eggs. These findings are consistent with an infection caused by Enterobius vermicularis. Bendazoles (e.g., mebendazole, albendazole) are the first-line treatment for this infection.  

These medications work by inhibiting the formation of microtubules, which form the cytoskeleton in the parasite’s cells. Albendazole is the medication of choice for ascariasis, pinworms, hookworms, and whipworms. It is also the first-line therapy for treating neurocysticercosis, which is caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia solium. Bendazoles are teratogenic so they should be avoided during pregnancy. Other side effects include bone marrow suppression and liver toxicity.  



Option Analysis

❌ Increases calcium permeability:
Incorrect: Praziquantel increases the permeability of parasitic cellular membranes to calcium ions, thereby leading to muscle paralysis and death. It is the first-line therapy against most trematodes (flukes) and cestodes (tapeworms). It is not effective against Enterobius vermicularis.  
❌ Increases chloride permeability  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action for ivermectin, which is an anthelmintic drug that can be used to treat infections by pathogens such as Onchocerca volvulus, Strongyloides stercoralis, Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichiura, and Enterobius vermicularis. While ivermectin has efficacy against Enterobius vermicularis, it is not the first-line therapy.  
✅  Inhibits tubulin polymerization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blocks acetylcholine at the myoneural junction.:
Incorrect: Piperazine blocks acetylcholine at the myoneural junction and can be used to treat infections by Ascaris lumbricoides. In contrast, this patient has perianal itching that is worse at night, which is more suggestive of infection by Enterobius vermicularis. Piperazine is not used in the treatment of infections by Enterobius vermicularis.  
❌ Uncouples oxidative phosphorylation  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action for niclosamide, which is an anthelmintic drug that can be used to treat various tapeworm infections. In contrast, this child has perianal itching that is worse at night. These findings are more suggestive of infection by the pinworm Enterobius vermicularis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of diarrhea and abdominal pain. He is accompanied by a parent who reports the child has had symptoms for three days, with 5-10 episodes of diarrhea per day. He vomited twice on the first day of symptoms but has had no vomiting since and has maintained good oral intake. Bright red blood was seen in the stool this morning. His abdominal pain is crampy and intermittent. The parent reports they were at an outdoor family picnic this past weekend where slightly undercooked hamburgers were served. They have not travelled recently and only drink bottled water. The patient does not have chronic medical conditions and was in good health prior to symptom onset. Family history includes Crohn’s disease in his paternal uncle. The patient has been growing well and keeping on his growth curve. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and blood pressure is 100/58 mmHg. On examination, the child is awake and in no acute distress. Mucus membranes are slightly dry. Abdominal examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness to palpation without guarding or rebound tenderness. Complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in the diagnostic workup?
questions.solution:
This child presenting with acute-onset bloody diarrhea after recent consumption of undercooked beef at an outdoor picnic likely has bacterial gastroenteritis. The next step in the evaluation of this patient’s symptoms is to order a stool culture. A stool culture will provide identification of the causative organism; in this case, it is likely Escherichia coli given his recent consumption of ground beef, which may have been undercooked or cross-contaminated.        

Children with acute diarrhea (lasting for less than two weeks) should first be evaluated for red flag symptoms, including high fever, blood or mucus in the stool, severe abdominal pain, and signs of dehydration. Patients without red flags can usually be treated with supportive care without the need for further workup as presumptive viral gastroenteritis.        

Children with acute diarrhea and red flag features likely have a severe case of viral gastroenteritis or a bacterial infection, such as from Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or Escherichia coli. If red flag symptoms are present, a complete blood count (CBC), complete metabolic panel (CMP), and stool studies should be ordered.        

In contrast to acute diarrhea, chronic diarrhea occurs when symptoms have lasted for two or more weeks. Children with chronic diarrhea and red flag symptoms, including bloody stools, may have an inflammatory process, such as inflammatory bowel disease or eosinophilic gastroenteritis. In addition to a CBC, CMP, and stool studies, inflammatory markers, colonoscopy (likely), and endoscopy (possibly) should be obtained. Chronic, non-bloody diarrhea with other red flag symptoms, such as fever or weight loss, should raise suspicion for pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, parasitic gastroenteritis, or hyperthyroidism. Pancreatic insufficiency and occasionally celiac disease, parasitic gastroenteritis, and hyperthyroidism will have steatorrhea. Children with chronic diarrhea who do not have red flag symptoms should be evaluated for lactase deficiency, toddler’s diarrhea, or irritable bowel syndrome.        

Option Analysis

✅ Stool culture:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fecal calprotectin:
Incorrect: Fecal calprotectin is usually elevated in inflammatory bowel disease, which also presents with bloody diarrhea, although symptoms are typically chronic rather than acute. This patient’s acute presentation of fever and bloody stools after consumption of undercooked beef is more concerning for a bacterial cause of diarrhea, and a stool culture would be the preferred next step in the workup.  
❌ Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A :
Incorrect: Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A test is helpful in the workup of celiac disease, which can cause chronic, watery diarrhea with steatorrhea. This patient’s acute presentation of bloody diarrhea and fever after consumption of undercooked beef is more concerning for a bacterial cause of diarrhea, and a stool culture would be the preferred next step in the workup. 
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is useful in the diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease, another potential cause of bloody diarrhea, but it is typically chronic rather than acute. This patient’s acute symptoms after recent consumption of undercooked beef are more concerning for a bacterial cause of diarrhea, and a stool culture is indicated prior to more invasive testing.  
❌ Thyroid-stimulating hormone with reflex free thyroxine (T4) :
Incorrect: Thyroid-stimulating hormone with reflex free thyroxine (T4) is used to evaluate for hyperthyroidism, which can cause diarrhea in addition to other symptoms, such as heart palpitations, heat intolerance, and weight loss. This patient’s acute onset of symptoms in addition to the development of bloody stool and fever after eating undercooked beef are concerning for an acute gastroenteritis from bacterial infection. Obtaining a stool culture is the best next step.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a 2-week history of diarrhea. The diarrhea is watery, occasionally mixed with blood, and associated with abdominal cramping and fever. He has also been fatigued, and his appetite has decreased. A 10-day course of amoxicillin was completed for otitis media 3 weeks ago. The child is not currently enrolled in daycare. No recent travel is reported. The child is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 140/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, and blood pressure is 82/46 mm Hg. The child appears lethargic but is arousable to verbal stimuli. Mucous membranes appear dry, and capillary refill is 4 seconds. Abdominal exam reveals diffuse tenderness without guarding or rebound. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Oral rehydration therapy and discharge on oral antibiotics
Abdominal computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This 4-year-old boy presents with a subacute history of diarrhea (>14 days). This clinical picture raises concern for antibiotic-associated diarrhea, with Clostridioides difficile infection being a possible etiology due to recent amoxicillin use and the absence of a travel history. Stabilization with intravenous fluids (e.g. normal saline) is the priority for this patient, given the signs of severe dehydration and hypovolemic shock.       

The first step when a pediatric patient presents with subacute diarrhea is to perform an ABCDE assessment to identify signs of respiratory distress or hemodynamic instability. If the patient is unstable, stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation takes priority. Immediate interventions may include obtaining intravenous access, initiating isotonic fluid resuscitation (e.g., normal saline or lactated Ringer’s), and placing the patient on continuous vital sign monitoring. Supplemental oxygen should be provided if necessary, and antibiotics, such as oral vancomycin for suspected C. difficile, may be considered. Once stabilized, further history, examination, and diagnostics can be pursued to determine the underlying cause.   

Option Analysis

❌ Oral rehydration therapy and discharge on oral antibiotics :
Incorrect: Although oral rehydration is appropriate for mild dehydration, this child shows signs of severe dehydration and hemodynamic instability, which require intravenous fluids. Discharging the child without addressing the unstable condition would be inappropriate.
✅ Intravenous (IV) normal saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stool ova and parasite studies:
Incorrect: Parasitic infections are less likely in this patient’s case due to the absence of travel history or other risk factors (e.g., daycare attendance, exposure to contaminated water). This patient’s diarrhea may be due to C. difficile, especially given the recent antibiotic use. Even so, stool studies are not the priority in an unstable patient. 
❌ Abdominal computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Imaging is unnecessary for patients with gastroenteritis unless there is suspicion of complicating conditions such as toxic megacolon or peritoneal signs. This patient should be stabilized before pursuing further testing. 
❌ Loperamide:
Incorrect: Antidiarrheal agents like loperamide are typically contraindicated in suspected infectious diarrhea, as they slow colonic transit and can increase the risk of toxin retention.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to clinic for evaluation of a 3-week history of diarrhea. The stools are described as greasy, foul-smelling, and pale, occurring 4–5 times daily. He has also had bloating, abdominal cramping, and increased flatulence. The parents report a decreased appetite and weight loss. There has been no fever, vomiting, or blood in the stools. The family recently returned from a camping trip. Vital signs are within normal limits. The child appears well. Mucous membranes appear tacky, and capillary refill is <2 seconds. Abdominal examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness without guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory stool studies are ordered. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on stool microscopy?

choices.text: Oval-shaped eggs with a terminal spine

questions.solution:
This child presents with a 3-week history of greasy, foul-smelling diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and weight loss, hallmark features of giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia. The recent camping trip and possible ingestion of contaminated water strongly support this diagnosis. Stool microscopy would likely reveal trophozoites with a pear-shaped appearance and four pairs of flagella, which are often described as resembling a "smiling face."       

The diagnostic workup for pediatric subacute infectious gastroenteritis includes a thorough history, physical examination, and targeted stool studies to identify the underlying pathogen. Stool cultures are essential for detecting bacterial causes, such as enteroaggregative Escherichia coli (EAEC) or Clostridioides difficile, with additional tests like toxin assays or nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) to detect specific bacterial toxins. Parasitic infections, including Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium, require stool ova and parasite (O&P) examination, antigen testing, or special stains for visualization.    

Option Analysis

❌ Oocysts with sporozoites :
Incorrect: This description matches Cryptosporidium, which causes watery diarrhea and is associated with recreational water exposure, such as public pools or lakes, or in immunocompromised individuals. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with giardiasis.
✅ Trophozoites with a pear-shaped appearance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oval-shaped eggs with a terminal spine:
Incorrect: These findings are characteristic of Schistosoma species, which cause symptoms like hematuria or dysentery and are typically found in freshwater snail habitats in specific regions. These symptoms do not match the presentation of diarrhea, bloating, and malabsorption in this case. Instead, this patient’s presentation is consistent with giardiasis. 
❌ Round cysts with multiple nuclei:
Incorrect: This finding describes Entamoeba histolytica, which causes bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. The absence of blood and the presence of greasy stools make this diagnosis unlikely in this case. Instead, this patient’s presentation is consistent with giardiasis. 
❌ Gram-positive rods with flagella:
Incorrect: This finding describes Clostridium difficile, which causes antibiotic-associated diarrhea, which is often watery and accompanied by fever or cramping. The greasy stools and weight loss described here are not typical of C. difficile infection. Instead, this patient’s presentation is consistent with giardiasis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl presents to the primary care office accompanied by her parent because of two weeks of frequent, greasy, foul-smelling diarrhea. Her parent reports she has not been as active as usual and occasionally reports abdominal pain. She has had frequent flatulence but no vomiting. The family vacationed in Vermont, United States last month where the child was swimming in a freshwater lake daily. Nobody else around her has been sick. Past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 138/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and blood pressure is 94/52 mmHg. On examination, the child appears tired but is alert and oriented. Mucus membranes are dry. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits except for mild tachycardia. The abdomen is soft and non-tender with hyperactive bowel sounds. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals the organism pictured below. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of diarrhea in this patient?

questions.solution:
This child is presenting with classic symptoms of parasitic gastroenteritis, including frequent, greasy, and foul-smelling diarrhea (i.e. steatorrhea); malaise; flatulence; and abdominal cramps. This child likely acquired the infection from accidental water ingestion while swimming in a freshwater lake in the northern United States. The flagellated, pear-shaped protozoa seen on stool microscopy confirms the diagnosis of Giardia duodenalis.        

A thorough history and physical examination can provide key details in the evaluation of diarrhea in children. Acute diarrhea is usually caused by an infectious etiology, either viral (most common), bacterial, or parasitic. Diarrhea caused by a virus is usually watery in nature and without red flags (i.e. blood or mucus in stool, severe abdominal pain or dehydration, and high fevers). It is most often caused by norovirus in countries where rotavirus vaccination is routine. Norovirus is highly contagious and spreads through close contact with infected individuals through a fecal-oral route. Day care centers, schools, healthcare facilities, and cruise ships are known to be associated with outbreaks.        

Bacterial gastroenteritis is often associated with acute bloody diarrhea or other red flags and may be caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or Escherichia coli. These infections may be associated with foodborne transmission from undercooked or cross-contaminated meat. In addition to food sources, Salmonella is known for transmission from handling reptiles, rodents, and other animals.        

Parasitic gastroenteritis can lead to either acute or chronic diarrhea and is most often caused by Giardia or Cryptosporidium. The diarrhea is usually non-bloody, watery, and it can be associated with steatorrhea. Transmission of parasitic disease primarily occurs through water, either from drinking contaminated water or during recreational activities in a contaminated body of water, such as a stream or lake.  

Option Analysis

✅ Giardia duodenalis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Campylobacter jejuni:
Incorrect: Campylobacter jejuni is a bacterial cause of gastroenteritis. It typically presents with diarrhea, fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody stools. The lack of bloody stools, presence of watery stools, and flatulence as well as the exposure to a freshwater lake makes Giardia duodenalis the more likely cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Norovirus:
Incorrect: Norovirus can cause watery diarrhea and abdominal pain, often accompanied by vomiting. This patient has evidence of steatorrhea, which is unlikely with norovirus; and the flagellated, pear-shaped protozoa in this patient’s stool sample are diagnostic of Giardia.  
❌ Salmonella typhi:
Incorrect: Salmonella typhi is the bacteria that causes Typhoid fever, an infection characterized by abdominal pain, high fever, rash, headache, and either diarrhea or constipation. While typhoid fever is also spread through contaminated water, it is usually encountered outside of the United States. In addition to the geographic location of infection, this patient’s lack of fever, steatorrhea, and the microscopy findings are more consistent with Giardia duodenalis infection.  
❌ Toxoplasma gondii:
Incorrect: Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that can cause a wide range of symptoms. Infected patients are often asymptomatic but may have flu-like symptoms, including malaise and body aches. Rarely, it can cause diarrhea when it affects the gastrointestinal system. The presence of greasy stools and flatulence (i.e. steatorrhea), exposure to a freshwater lake, and microscopy findings makes Giardia duodenalis the cause of this patient’s symptoms.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic in winter with a 2-day history of watery diarrhea and intermittent non-bilious vomiting. The caregiver reports that fever and vomiting began suddenly 1 day before the onset of diarrhea. The boy has had six episodes of diarrhea and three episodes of vomiting in the past 24 hours. He has been drinking small amounts of water but is less active. There has been no recent travel or known exposure to contaminated food or water. Several children at daycare have had similar symptoms. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg, heart rate is 130 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the child is alert but appears tired. No rashes are noted. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Stool PCR testing is positive for a double-stranded RNA virus. Which of the following elements of the history or physical examination is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 2-year-old patient with sick contacts at daycare presents in winter with vomiting that preceded watery diarrhea and fever, suggesting acute infectious gastroenteritis. Stool PCR detected a double-stranded RNA virus, which is most consistent with rotavirus, a common cause of pediatric gastroenteritis. Illness is more likely and more severe in infants and toddlers who are unvaccinatedor incompletely vaccinated.

Obtaining and interpreting a focused history and physical examination involves identifying key symptoms, assessing hydration, and considering the likely etiology. History should address the duration, frequency, and character of stools. Watery stools favor a noninflammatory process, while blood or mucus suggest an inflammatory cause, such as Shigella, Campylobacter, or Yersinia. Additional history may include vomiting, fever, abdominal pain, and recent exposures including ill contacts, contaminated food or water, and travel. Seasons can provide clues, since rotavirus and Yersinia are more common in winter, whereas Campylobacter peaks in warmer months.

The physical examination should evaluate for dehydration by assessing mucous membranes, skin turgor, capillary refill, and vital signs. Hyperactive bowel sounds are typical in gastroenteritis, and the abdomen may be diffusely tender. Conjunctivitis can point toward adenovirus.

Option Analysis

❌ Rhinorrhea:
Incorrect: Rhinorrhea is more typical of viral upper respiratory infections. While mild nasal congestion can occasionally accompany viral gastroenteritis, especially in adenovirus infection (a DNA virus), this patient’s presentation is more consistent with rotavirus (a double-stranded RNA virus) which primarily causes fever and gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting and watery diarrhea.
✅ Unvaccinated status:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoactive bowel sounds:
Incorrect: Acute viral gastroenteritis typically causes hyperactive bowel sounds due to increased intestinal motility. Hypoactive sounds suggest ileus or another process that decreases motility, which does not fit this presentation.
❌ Exposure to reptiles:
Incorrect: Contact with turtles, snakes, or lizards raises concern for nontyphoidal Salmonella infection, a gram-negative bacterium that typically causes inflammatory diarrhea that may be bloody or mucoid, with prominent abdominal pain and high fever. However, this case includes vomiting preceding watery diarrhea in winter, a daycare cluster, and a stool PCR positive for a double-stranded RNA virus; this presentation is consistent with rotavirus.
❌ Bloody stools:
Incorrect: Blood or mucus in the stool suggests inflammatory diarrhea from invasive bacteria such as Shigella, Campylobacter, Salmonella. This case is instead highly suggestive of rotavirus, a double-stranded RNA virus which causes noninflammatory watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with worsening abdominal pain that began all of a sudden after eating pizza two nights ago. The patient reports the pain has progressively worsened and is now 8 out of 10 in severity. He reports no change in bowel movements during this time, but he has had a decreased appetite and moderate nausea. Medical history includes lactose intolerance. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 108/66 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows right lower quadrant pain with passive right hip extension. Which of the following will most likely provide definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has worsening right lower quadrant (RLQ) abdominal pain for 2 days, mild fever, and positive Psoas sign (right lower quadrant pain elicited with passive right hip extension). He most likely has acute appendicitis. The treatment of choice is surgical removal of the appendix (appendectomy), which can be achieved via open surgery or laparoscopy.  

Diagnosis of appendicitis can be made clinically. However, abdominal CT scan can be used to confirm the diagnosis and for surgical planning prior to appendectomy.  

The abdominal pain associated with appendicitis typically begins as poorly localized pain in the periumbilical region, which then migrates to McBurney point in the RLQ. McBurney point is about two-thirds of the way from the umbilicus to the right anterior superior iliac spine. Patients with a retrocecal appendix may also report right flank pain due to psoas muscle irritation.  

Common physical exam findings include Rovsing, obturator, and psoas signs. Rovsing sign is RLQ pain elicited on palpation of the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Obturator sign is RLQ pain with right hip flexion followed by internal rotation. Pain occurs since the inflamed appendix irritates the obturator internus muscle. Psoas sign is RLQ pain elicited with passive right hip extension, which stretches the psoas muscle and causes friction against the inflamed appendix. Common laboratory findings include a hypokalemic, hypochloremic, metabolic alkalosis due to vomiting and leukocytosis with left shift.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ IV antibiotics:
Incorrect: While some evidence exists for nonoperative management of non-perforated acute appendicitis with antibiotics, this option is only indicated for a very small subset of patients in which surgery is contraindicated or refused.   
❌ Oral rehydration:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration is the treatment of choice for gastroenteritis and small asymptomatic kidney stones less than 10 mm in diameter. Patients with gastroenteritis would present with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Patients with kidney stones would present with flank pain and urinary symptoms. Psoas sign would be negative in either condition  
✅ Surgical intervention:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dietary restriction:
Incorrect: Dietary restriction is the treatment of choice for lactose intolerance. Patients with lactose intolerance present with temporary bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence shortly after consumption of dairy products. Psoas sign would be negative, and abdominal symptoms do not typically persist for 2 days.   
❌ Polyethylene glycol:
Incorrect: Laxatives, such as polyethylene glycol, are used in the treatment of constipation. Patients with constipation present with abdominal pain, decreased bowel movements, and bloating. However, constipation would not cause a positive Psoas sign.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate right lower quadrant abdominal pain. The pain is sharp, stabbing, and has progressively worsened. He has also had decreased oral intake and an episode of vomiting that has since resolved. Past medical and surgical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 107/67 mmHg, and pulse is 106/min. The examiner passively extends the patient’s right leg with the patient lying on his left side. This maneuver reproduces pain in the right lower quadrant. Which of the following best describes the physical examination finding present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features of acute appendicitis, including right lower quadrant pain, anorexia, and associated vomiting. Additionally, the pain is reproduced with passive extension of the right hip, consistent with a positive iliopsoas sign (also termed the Thomas test).

The iliopsoas muscle originates on the outer vertebral bodies of T12 and L1-L3. The muscle inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. This muscle is largely responsible for hip flexion and thus is important for standing, walking, and running. Passive extension of the hip places strain on the iliopsoas and any nearby structures or anatomically associated pathology.

Common etiologies associated with a positive iliopsoas sign include acute appendicitis, sigmoid colitis, or lymphadenopathy. Rarely, a positive iliopsoas sign may indicate a psoas abscess, which is a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment. When these conditions are suspected, definitive diagnosis is best achieved with a contrast-enhanced CT.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliopsoas sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Murphy sign is performed by pressing firmly in the right upper quadrant, having the patient inspire, and then exhale slowly. A positive test indicates worsened pain with expiration and can signify underlying cholecystitis.  
❌ McBurney point tenderness  :
Incorrect: McBurney point tenderness is elicited by palpation at McBurney point, which is one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. Tenderness at this location suggests acute appendicitis.  
❌ Rovsing sign  :
Incorrect: Rovsing sign is performed by palpating the left lower quadrant. The test is positive if left lower quadrant palpation elicits pain in the right lower quadrant. A positive test can be suggestive of acute appendicitis.  
❌ Homan sign  :
Incorrect: Homan sign refers to reproducible pain with forced dorsiflexion of the foot. A positive test can be indicative of lower extremity deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to worsening abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting for the last 2 days. Her parents report she has also had mild non-bloody diarrhea and the pain does not improve with defecation. When asked to localize the pain, the patient points to the right lower quadrant of her abdomen. She rates the pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale. Her medical history is non-contributory. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mmHg. On examination, palpation of the left lower quadrant of the abdomen elicits pain in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory tests are obtained and reveal a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. Which of the following is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This 8-year-old girl presents with greater than 24 hours of fever, nausea, vomiting, positive Rovsing sign (right lower quadrant pain that is elicited with palpation of the left lower quadrant), and worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain. She most likely has appendicitis.  

Appendicitis is caused by an initial obstruction of the appendix, which leads to buildup of intestinal fluid, mucous, and gut flora (primarily Escheria coli and Bacillus fragilis) in the obstructed appendix. In children, the most common cause of appendiceal obstruction is lymphoid hyperplasia. In adults, the most common cause of obstruction is fecalith impaction. Other rarer causes include carcinoid tumor of the appendix, pinworm, eosinophilic appendicitis, and actinomycosis.  

As a result of the obstruction and subsequent buildup, the appendix grows in size and compresses the nearby afferent visceral nerves, which are carried to the T10 segment of the spinal cord, resulting in the initial periumbilical pain. The inflammation can then spread to the serosa of the appendix and the parietal peritoneum of the abdomen. Irritation of the parietal peritoneum, which is innervated by somatic nerves that also supply the overlying skin, results in migration of the pain to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.    

The spread of this inflammation ultimately leads to weakening of the appendix wall, which can lead to appendiceal rupture. Bacteria can then escape into the peritoneum, leading to peritonitis and abscess formation.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Noncaseating granulomas:
Incorrect: Noncaseating granulomas can be seen in the affected bowel segments of patients with Crohn disease. Crohn disease typically presents with chronic fatigue, crampy abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and low-grade fever. Moreover, non-caseating granulomas are also classically seen in sarcoidosis. However, this condition rarely causes gastrointestinal symptoms.  
❌ Ectopic gastric tissue  :
Incorrect: Ectopic gastric tissue is associated with Meckel diverticulum, a congenital gastrointestinal anomaly which results from failure of involution of the omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct. Patients with Meckel diverticulum would present with abdominal pain and hematochezia. In this case, however, appendicitis is a much more likely diagnosis.  
✅ Lymphoid hyperplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gram-negative bacterial infection:
Incorrect: Yersinia enterocolitica, a gram-negative bacteria, can cause mesenteric lymphadenitis, which is also known as pseudoappendicitis due its similar presentation. Moreover, patients may experience bloody diarrhea. The pathogen is transmitted via undercooked foods, contaminated water, and contact with infected animals and their feces. In contrast, this patient has nonbloody diarrhea and no history of risk factors that may expose her to the pathogen.  
❌ “Target sign” on ultrasound:
Incorrect: A “target sign” on ultrasound is associated with intussusception, which is defined as telescoping of one segment of the bowel into an adjacent segment. Patients with intussusception would present with colicky abdominal pain and currant jelly stools. Moreover, a sausage-shaped mass may be palpable on physical examination.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and worsening abdominal pain for the last 12 hours. She states the pain started all of sudden with no inciting factors. Her symptoms were not associated with any particular meal, and she denies any recent travel. The patient has a history of mild asthma, for which she takes an albuterol inhaler as needed. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mmHg. Physical examination shows right lower abdominal pain that is elicited with deep palpation. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. A urine β-hCG test is ordered and returns negative. Leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This young woman presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, right lower abdominal pain for the last 12 hours, and positive Psoas sign. She most likely has appendicitis. However, in a woman of child-bearing age, it is important to determine whether or not she is pregnant as this information will determine what diagnostic test to order. If the patient is not pregnant, an abdominal CT scan should be ordered. If the patient is pregnant, right lower quadrant (RLQ) ultrasound should be ordered (to minimize fetal radiation exposure).

Differential diagnosis of right lower quadrant pain in a woman of child-bearing age includes appendicitis, nephrolithiasis, inflammatory bowel disease, ectopic pregnancy, pelvic inflammatory disease, ovarian torsion, endometriosis, ovarian cysts, and pancreatitis. Further tests can be considered following history and physical to narrow the differential diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography of the abdomen:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: Abdominal X-ray is used in the diagnosis of a variety of abdominal pathologies, such as small bowel obstruction or intestinal perforation secondary to peptic ulcers. However, it is not indicated in a patient with suspected appendicitis.  
❌ Right lower quadrant ultrasound  :
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound can be used to diagnose appendicitis in pregnant patients when clinical features are unclear. However, this patient has a negative urine beta-hCG. In non-pregnant adults, abdominal CT would be preferred over ultrasound.  
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is used in the diagnosis of upper gastrointestinal pathologies, particularly those above the ligament of Treitz. Some specific diseases diagnosed via upper endoscopy include peptic ulcer disease, esophageal mucosal tears from forceful vomiting (Mallory-Weis tear), and gastric cancers.   
❌ Immediate surgery:
Incorrect: Immediate surgery would be indicated in a patient with hemodynamic instability secondary to a number of abdominal pathologies. However, in this patient with normal blood pressure and heart rate, diagnostics tests should be performed first to identify the exact cause of this patient’s abdominal pain.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain. The pain started 12 hours ago and was initially vague and located around the umbilicus. The pain has become more severe and has shifted to the right lower abdomen. The patient also reports three episodes of vomiting associated with nausea. The rest of the review of the system is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination of the abdomen shows maximal tenderness with guarding and rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant about the two-thirds distance from the umbilicus to the anterior superior iliac spine. Laboratory evaluation reveals a leukocyte count of 14,000/mm3. The patient is prepared for urgent surgery. Which of the following landmarks will help the surgeons to identify the diseased organ during surgery?
questions.solution:
This patient has a classic presentation of acute appendicitis. During surgical removal of the appendix, the teniae coli can be used as a landmark. Teniae coli are three separate longitudinal ribbons of smooth muscle outside the ascending, transverse, descending, and sigmoid colons. They are visible and can be seen just below the serosa or fibrosa. The bands converge at the root of the vermiform appendix. During surgery, the appendix can be located by following the taenia to their origin at the base of the cecum.  



The appendix is usually located 2-cm beneath the ileocecal valve in the RLQ at a retrocal location. The initial periumbilical pain in appendicitis is referred pain due to the irritation of the general visceral afferent fibers (T10) of the autonomic nervous system, secondary to the luminal distension stretching of the smooth muscle. The subsequent shift of the pain to the right lower quadrant (RLQ) results from irritation of the parietal peritoneum and the abdominal wall which is located at the McBurney point (two-third distance from the umbilicus to the anterior superior iliac spine). With peritoneal irritation, the abdominal wall becomes very sensitive to palpation or sudden release of pressure. (i.e. rebound tenderness).    

While the retrocecal location is the most common location of the appendix, its location is highly variable and it can be located in almost any area of the abdomen, depending on developmental abnormalities, pregnancy, and prior abdominal surgeries. This can lead to variability in the clinical presentation of appendicitis. For example, the obturator sign is pain with internal rotation of the right hip, suggestive of a pelvic appendix. The psoas sign which is pain with external rotation or passive extension of the right hip is suggestive of a retrocecal appendix  



Option Analysis

❌ Ligament of Treitz:
Incorrect: The duodenum is demarcated from the stomach by the pylorus and from the jejunum by the ligament of Treitz. The appendix is located distal to the ileum and cannot be identified by locating the ligament of Treitz.  
❌ Lesser omentum:
Incorrect: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach (hepatogastric ligament) and the first part of the duodenum (hepatoduodenal ligament). It does not cover the large intestine and is not an important landmark for appendectomy.  
❌ Greater omentum:
Incorrect: The greater omentum extends from the greater curvature of the stomach, passing in front of the small intestines, and folds back to ascendthe transverse colon before reaching the posterior abdominal wall. It does not cover the large intestine and is not an important landmark for appendectomy.  
❌ Peyer patches:
Incorrect: Peyer patches are an important part of gut-associated lymphoid tissues usually found in the distal jejunum and the ileum. They are absent in the appendix.  
✅ Teniae coli:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
